message: I'm a fan of supervisord
If it's a daemon I wrote (as opposed to apache or the like), I use supervisord.
there's a lot available to choose from, including monir, supervisor, ruby's god, daemontools, runit, upstart, launchd, etc
@robotadam Ditto, except daemontools
upstart usually, since it is already there
I use upstart, as it's already part of my ubuntu 10.10 systems
and then there's larger ones like nagios
upstart is going to win out because it is easy, and it is built into ubuntu
I personally like upstart followed by runit, and have been meaning to check out supervisord
and while the conf syntax is nice, it would be nicer with documentation
Note that Nagios is typically for alerting, not keeping processes up constantly
God is kind of flaky in my experience, though that was about 1.5-2 years ago
I started using monit and I'm quite happy with it so far.
so just use upstart
we use zabbix for monitoring, and supervisord for keeping various services alive.
Angel! http://bit.ly/gaBep1
I like supervisord
supervisord if I'm using shared hosting like webfaction
upstart
upstart and I definitely second @andrewgodwin 's request for more documentation ;-)
I use supervisord for all kinds of crazy shit.
If you want something to 'just work', you can't go wrong with upstart
I use supervisord, e.g for gunicorn processes used to serve Django sites
I use supervisord
I use Upstart. But better documentation would be nice...
I use monit but am curious about supervisord.
supervisord ftw
supervisord ++
another vote for supervisord. easy to configure, easy to add services, and you can temporarily turn off supervisor'ed processes.
Upstart
personally, I like daemontools/runit
+1 for supervisord
Supervisord!

At my company we use a combination of Nagios XI (3 is good too though), Munin and collectd as well as some custom Python and Perl scripts that I use for spying on developers when they mess with my servers.
which process monitors work across a cluster of servers? i.e. i want to setup a single server to monitor http/nginx,phusion,mysql,memcached,redis
Supervisord and serverdensity for monitoring :)

If I have to set it up myself, supervisord. If the install process takes care of it for me (aptitude sets up the init scripts, or homebrew gives me launchd configuration files) I use the default OS monitor.
